(12 points, suggested time 25 minutes) Students have a battery of <math alttext="e m f"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="script E"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with negligible internal resistance and many identical resistive heating elements and will connect a circuit so the heating elements can be used to heat some water. Each of the heating elements has resistance <math alttext="R"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) First the students consider connecting the heating elements in series with the battery, as shown above. One student says that to heat the water faster, they should use as many heating elements as possible. i. Write an equation for the power <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> dissipated by a circuit containing <math alttext="N"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> heating elements in series, in terms of <math alttext="script E"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="N"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.
ii. Does your equation support or refute the student’s claim about the time it takes to heat the water? Justify your answer.

(b) Another student suggests that connecting the heating elements in parallel might be a better idea. The student says that a certain number of elements in parallel will heat the water faster than the same number of elements in series, because the current in the parallel circuit will be less. i. Write an equation for the power <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> dissipated by a circuit containing <math alttext="N"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> heating elements in parallel, in terms of <math alttext="script E"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="N"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.
ii. Does your equation support or refute the student’s claim about the time it takes to heat the water? Justify your answer.
iii. Is the student’s claim about the current correct? Justify your answer.
